item.title: Restraint, not rhetoric for regional stability
item.description: SINCE the mid-20th century, the One China Policy has stood as a foundational pillar of Asian and global diplomacy. At its core, the policy reflects a widely accepted diplomatic stance that there is only one sovereign ‘China’, represented by the People’s Republic of China, and that Taiwan is part of that single China — a position that most states agree to and adopt......

item.title: Sham academy, sham education
item.description: THE Sharmin Academy, a private profiteering venture in the name of a school at Purana Paltan in Dhaka, has sparked criticism lately as the so-called children’s school sprawled on a toddler in the middle of January in the academy owner’s room mercilessly beating the boy child by the face and threatening the him with stapling up his lips if the atrocities were disclosed to anyone......

item.title: Selling war
item.description: SINCE the end of World War II, the global landscape has been persistently scarred by hundreds of wars and armed conflicts. To understand their persistence is to ask a question: who is the most responsible? The answer lies not in a single entity but in a pervasive system where conflict is not merely fought but actively sold. This sale occurs through a multi-faceted......

item.title: Can remittances shape structural economic resilience?
item.description: IN A year marked by global economic uncertainty and domestic policy shifts, Bangladesh’s remittance inflows in 2025 revealed both the strength and fragility of an economy that remains deeply reliant on its expatriate workforce. Far from being a peripheral statistic, remittance has been one of the most consequential macroeconomic variables in Bangladesh’s recent......

item.title: Electric rickshaws need rules, not turf wars
